Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: Let them be only thine own, And not strangers’with thee.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: When thou beatest thine olive-tree, thou shalt not go over the boughs again; it shall be for the stranger, for the fatherless, and for the widow.

Version: Eighteen Treatises from the Mishna
Content: When a stranger has lent money to an Israelite upon the security of leavened articles, they may be applied to use after the Passover; but when an Israelite has lent money to a stranger upon leavened

Version: The Rashi chumash by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: The stranger in your midst will rise ever higher above you, and you will descend lower and lower.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: Thou shalt not pervert the justice due to the stranger, or to the fatherless; nor take the widow’s raiment to pledge.

Version: The Rashi chumash by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: You shall not oppress a hired laborer who is poor and needy, of your brothers [(One who does so transgresses two negative commandments, this and Leviticus 19:13)], or of your stranger [a righteous

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: And I charged your judges at that time, saying: ‘Hear the causes between your brethren, and judge righteously between a man and his brother, and the stranger that is with him.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: The sons of the stranger fade away, and come trembling out of their close places.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: Six days thou shalt do thy work, but on the seventh day thou shalt rest; that thine ox and thine ass may have rest, and the son of thy handmaid, and the stranger, may be refreshed.

Version: The Rashi Ketuvim by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: I am a stranger in the land. Do not hide from me [the secrets of] Your mitzvoth.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: The stranger did not lodge in the street; My doors I opened to the roadside.

Version: Pentateuch with Rashi's commentary by M. Rosenbaum and A.M. Silbermann
Content: כי קדש הם BECAUSE THEY ARE HOLY — i. e. holy in the highest degree. From this we derive the prohibition against a “stranger” (a non-priest) eating anything that is holy in the highest degree (Makkot

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: And they shall eat those things wherewith atonement was made, to consecrate and to sanctify them; but a stranger shall not eat thereof, because they are holy.

Version: Pentateuch with Rashi's commentary by M. Rosenbaum and A.M. Silbermann
Content: שני מגורי — means the days of my being a stranger. All my days I have been a stranger in other peoples’ lands.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: and her two sons; of whom the name of the one was Gershom; for he said: ‘I have been a stranger in a strange land’;

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: He that is surety for a stranger shall smart for it; But he that hateth them that strike hands is secure.

Version: Daf Shevui
Content: Zera said: There is no difficulty. One ruling refers to [a woman who has assigned to the stranger] all her property; the other to [a woman who assigned to a stranger] a part of her property.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: They slay the widow and the stranger, And murder the fatherless.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: And He said unto Abram: ‘Know of a surety that thy seed shall be a stranger in a land that is not theirs, and shall serve them; and they shall afflict them four hundred years;

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: And David said unto the young man that told him: ‘Whence art thou?’ And he answered: ‘I am the son of an Amalekite stranger.’

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: And if a stranger who is a settler with thee be waxen rich, and thy brother be waxen poor beside him, and sell himself unto the stranger who is a settler with thee, or to the offshoot of a stranger’s family,

Version: Pentateuch with Rashi's commentary by M. Rosenbaum and A.M. Silbermann
Content: וגר לא תלחץ AND THOU SHALT NOT OPPRESS THE STRANGER — In numerous passages (36 in number) does the Torah offer a caution about the ill-treatment of the stranger, because his original character is bad (Bava Metzia 59b).

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: then thou shalt say before the LORD thy God: ‘I have put away the hallowed things out of my house, and also have given them unto the Levite, and unto the stranger, to the fatherless, and to the widow

Version: The Rashi chumash by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: The congregation — one statute shall there be for you and for the stranger that sojourns (among you), an everlasting statute unto your generations: As you are, so shall the stranger be, before the L-rd.

Version: The Mishna with Obadiah Bartenura by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: If there were three brothers, two of them married to two sisters, and one of them married to a stranger — if one of the sisters' husbands died, and the one married to the stranger took his wife (in

Version: The Mishna with Obadiah Bartenura by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: If there were three brothers, two of them married to two sisters, and one of them married to a stranger [i.e., kin to neither of the wives] — if one of the sisters' husbands died, and the one

Version: Eliyahu Munk, HaChut Hameshulash
Content: גר הייתי בארץ נכריה. A stranger in a land which is not my birthplace.

Version: The Rashi Ketuvim by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: Let another praise you, and not your [own] mouth; a stranger, and not your [own] lips.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: Unto whom alone the land was given, And no stranger passed among them.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: your little ones, your wives, and thy stranger that is in the midst of thy camp, from the hewer of thy wood unto the drawer of thy water;

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: And if thy brother be waxen poor, and his means fail with thee; then thou shalt uphold him: as a stranger and a settler shall he live with thee.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: But the soul that doeth aught with a high hand, whether he be home-born or a stranger, the same blasphemeth the LORD; and that soul shall be cut off from among his people.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: When thou gatherest the grapes of thy vineyard, thou shalt not glean it after thee; it shall be for the stranger, for the fatherless, and for the widow.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: both he that is home-born among the children of Israel, and the stranger that sojourneth among them: ye shall have one law for him that doeth aught in error.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: And thou shalt not glean thy vineyard, neither shalt thou gather the fallen fruit of thy vineyard; thou shalt leave them for the poor and for the stranger: I am the LORD your God.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: Therefore I said unto the children of Israel: No soul of you shall eat blood, neither shall any stranger that sojourneth among you eat blood.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: And she bore a son, and he called his name Gershom; for he said: ‘I have been a stranger in a strange land.’

Version: The Targum of Jonathan ben Uzziel, trans. J. W. Etheridge, London, 1862
Content: A sojourner or a hired stranger shall not eat thereof.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: And if a stranger sojourn with thee in your land, ye shall not do him wrong.

Version: The Rashi chumash by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: Assemble the people: the men [to learn], the women [to hear], and the little ones, [to confer reward on those who bring them], and the stranger in your gates, so that they hear and so that they learn and fear the L-rd your G-d and observe to do all the words of this Torah.

Version: The Rashi chumash by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: One Torah and one judgment shall there be for you and for the stranger who sojourns with you.

Version: Pentateuch with Rashi's commentary by M. Rosenbaum and A.M. Silbermann
Content: כי גרים הייתם [LOVE THE STRANGER] FOR YE WERE STRANGERS — Do not reproach thy fellow man for a fault which is also thine (cf. Rashi on Exodus 22:20; Bava Metzia 59b).

Version: The Rashi chumash by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: And the L-rd said to Moses and Aaron [(on the fourteenth of Nissan)]: This is the statute of the paschal offering: No stranger [(Both a heretical Jew and a non-Jew are implied)] may eat of it.

Version: Eliyahu Munk, HaChut Hameshulash
Content: נשיא אלוהים, “a prince of G’d,” neither stranger or resident stranger as Avraham had described himself.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: And a stranger shalt thou not oppress; for ye know the heart of a stranger, seeing ye were strangers in the land of Egypt.

Version: Eliyahu Munk, HaChut Hameshulash
Content: בארץ נכריה. The meaning of the name Gershom, i.e. a stranger in a distant land.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: Ye shall have one manner of law, as well for the stranger, as for the home-born; for I am the LORD your God.’

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: Whosoever compoundeth any like it, or whosoever putteth any of it upon a stranger, he shall be cut off from his people.’

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: And thou shalt rejoice in all the good which the LORD thy God hath given unto thee, and unto thy house, thou, and the Levite, and the stranger that is in the midst of thee.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: He doth execute justice for the fatherless and widow, and loveth the stranger, in giving him food and raiment.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: One law shall be to him that is homeborn, and unto the stranger that sojourneth among you.’

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: My son, if thou art become surety for thy neighbour, If thou hast struck thy hands for a stranger—

Version: The Rashi chumash by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: You shall not eat any carcass. To the stranger in your gates, [a ger toshav (a "resident stranger"), one who has taken it upon himself not to serve idolatry, but who eats carcass] shall you give it

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: I am become a stranger unto my brethren, And an alien unto my mother's children.

Version: The Targum of Jonathan ben Uzziel, trans. J. W. Etheridge, London, 1862
Content: Have pity then (yourselves) upon the stranger, for you were strangers in the land of Mizraim.

Version: The Rashi chumash by Rabbi Shraga Silverstein
Content: And you shall rejoice in your festival: you — your son, your daughter, your man-servant, your maid-servant — the Levite, the stranger, the orphan, and the widow, who are in your gates.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: The heart knoweth its own bitterness; And with its joy no stranger can intermeddle.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: The sons of the stranger fade away, And come halting out of their close places.

Version: Sefaria Community Translation
Content: 74. That the stranger [a non-Cohen] shall not serve in the Temple as it says “and the stranger shall not approach you.” (Bamidbar 18:4)

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: Thou shalt not abhor an Edomite, for he is thy brother; thou shalt not abhor an Egyptian, because thou wast a stranger in his land.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: Love ye therefore the stranger; for ye were strangers in the land of Egypt.

Version: The Holy Scriptures: A New Translation (JPS 1917)
Content: And a stranger shalt thou not wrong, neither shalt thou oppress him; for ye were strangers in the land of Egypt.
